citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Three dogs had excessively matted hair and one dog had an excessive amount of hard material on the molars.
*Lani (id# 7800002127, DOB 2/23/17) a small white female dog, has an excessive amount of hard brown and gray
material on most of her teeth. The molars are entirely coated with this material. Poor dental health can make it difficult to
chew food and could cause pain and discomfort to the dog, as well as lead to further health issues. The licensee must
have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to provide appropriate treatment. These medical records must be
available for APHIS inspection.
*Fred (id#9944, DOB 3/31/22), a male red Miniature Poodle, has excessively matted and twisted hair on his face, head,
body, legs and feet.
*Sadie (id#7566, DOB 5/17/16) a black female Poodle, has excessively matted and twisted hair on her body, legs, feet,
head and face. The toenails are also excessively long and are curling under. The molars have an excessive amount of
hard, brown and gray material coating on them. Failure to trim nails can lead to overgrowth which can cause pain, injury,
and/or gait abnormalities. Poor dental health could cause pain and discomfort to the dog, as well as lead to further health
issues. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to provide appropriate treatment for the
dental issue. These medical records must be available for APHIS inspection.
*Rainbow Fluffy (id#930819, DOB 4/15/22) a white Bichon mix had excessively matted and twisted hair on her face, head,
body, legs and feet.
Matted hair can result in skin problems, can be painful, and can compromise the hair’s ability to provide protection from
the heat or cold. The licensee must remove the matted hair from these animals and must establish an effective program
of haircoat maintenance. Toenails must be trimmed and maintained to appropriate lengths to prevent pain, injury or gait
abnormalities.
Correction date: 16 March 2024

The Program of Veterinary Care does not include plans for preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and
unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The written Program of
Veterinary care must address a preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly
trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. These plans are important to maintain the health and
well being of the dogs and must be addressed in the in the written program of veterinary care that is signed by the
attending veterinarian. The licensee must work with the attending veterinarian to design a preventative program for the
health and well being of the dogs.
Correction date: 16 March 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Three dogs had excessively matted hair and one dog had an excessive amount of hard material on the molars. 
 *Lani (id# 7800002127, DOB 2/23/17) a small white female dog, has an excessive amount of hard brown and gray 
material on most of her teeth. The molars are entirely coated with this material. Poor dental health can make it difficult to 
chew food and could cause pain and discomfort to the dog, as well as lead to further health issues. The licensee must 
have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to provide appropriate treatment. These medical records must be 
available for APHIS inspection. 
*Fred (id#9944, DOB 3/31/22), a male red Miniature Poodle, has excessively matted and twisted hair on his face, head, 
body, legs and feet.  
*Sadie (id#7566, DOB 5/17/16) a black female Poodle, has excessively matted and twisted hair on her body, legs, feet, 
head and face. The toenails are also excessively long and are curling under. The molars have an excessive amount of 
hard, brown and gray material coating on them. Failure to trim nails can lead to overgrowth which can cause pain, injury, 
and/or gait abnormalities. Poor dental health could cause pain and discomfort to the dog, as well as lead to further health 
issues. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to provide appropriate treatment for the 
dental issue. These medical records must be available for APHIS inspection. 
*Rainbow Fluffy (id#930819, DOB 4/15/22) a white Bichon mix had excessively matted and twisted hair on her face, head, 
body, legs and feet.  
Matted hair can result in skin problems, can be painful, and can compromise the hair’s ability to provide protection from 
the heat or cold. The licensee must remove the matted hair from these animals and must establish an effective program 
of haircoat maintenance. Toenails must be trimmed and maintained to appropriate lengths to prevent pain, injury or gait 
abnormalities. 
 
Correction date: 16 March 2024 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care does not include plans for preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and 
unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The written Program of 
Veterinary care must address a preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly 
trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. These plans are important to maintain the health and

well being of the dogs and must be addressed in the in the written program of veterinary care that is signed by the 
attending veterinarian. The licensee must work with the attending veterinarian to design a preventative program for the 
health and well being of the dogs. 
Correction date: 16 March 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
